timeline.bodyText: Is this access level escalation required, for the implementation class? (The public methods will still be public.)
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: Yeah...that's because anything outside of the package wouldn't have access to the RxSubscriptionOperation object. That being said, rather than making this public, I created a top level class called RxOperations where we can put of the Rx-operation related objects. That, we can make public.
replies.author: rjuliano

timeline.bodyText: does it need to be public?
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: This one does, but now lives under RxOperations.
replies.author: rjuliano

timeline.bodyText: Maybe do this as an inner class (FooConsumer extends Consumer), and initialize it inside the constructor body? S.t. private final Consumer<String> onConnected; is up with the other ordinary declarations?
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.bodyText: Is there any way to bundle this into the ConnectionState object?
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: Good call on this one. Rather that doing it this way, I created a ConnectionStateEvent that has a connectionState and subscriptionId properties. We can expand on that down the road.
replies.author: rjuliano

timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: I looked into this, but it will require some additional plumbing to surface those events from the SubscriptionEndpoint class. I will make note to create a task for this.
replies.author: rjuliano

timeline.bodyText: I'd add an import ...  for RxSubscriptionOperation.. directly just to cut down on some of this boiler plate a tiny bit.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.message: Created a class to hold rx-operation objects
